title: MLB DFS Bargains: Wednesday 9/25
text:
Welcome to MLB DFS Bargains. We’ll split the analysis into three groups: very cheap, mid-tier, and expensive. A greater emphasis will be placed on the lower end of the price scale.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

There are 12 games available tonight.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

DIRT CHEAP BARGAINS

Tim Melville – SP – Colorado Rockies (at Giants)

Melville is a below average, soft-tossing righty. He’s among the worst pitchers in the league, although his numbers have been greatly affected by Coors Field. In a super small sample, he’s allowed an 8.04 ERA at home (15.2 innings) and a 2.13 ERA on the road (12.2 innings). We shouldn’t let this split affect our analysis beyond allowing the possibility that sea level Melville might not be entirely futile. To return value on his price tag, he need only supply about five innings and four strikeouts. The Giants offense is weak, and Oracle Park is pitcher friendly.

Brian Dozier – 2B – Washington Nationals (vs Drew Smyly)

Dozier is a classic platoon target. Although he’s performed rather unimpressively overall, he’s still mashed lefties to the tune of .281/.379/.509. As in his peak, he remains an extreme pull hitter. Smyly is excessively homer prone (2.59 HR/9) in part because he allows a lot of pulled, fly ball contact. Dozier projects to deliver around one-quarter of a home run with upside to go wild.

Brad Miller – 2B/3B – Philadelphia Phillies (vs Anibal Sanchez)

Story continues

The Phillies are using Miller in the heart of the lineup. He’ll likely bat fifth tonight. The juiced baseball has helped to reinvigorate the 29-year-old – he’s popped 10 home runs in 155 plate appearances. Strikeouts and a low batting average remain a problem for him, rendering Miller something of an all-or-nothing power target. He projects for a one-in-four chance to homer versus Sanchez. Notably, the Nationals righty is not homer prone, although he does have some modest issues with left-handed hitters.

Khris Davis – OF – Oakland Athletics (at Andrew Heaney)

Davis’s largely absentee 2019 campaign has been well-document. While he’s shown a few flashes of life in September, it’s not enough to declare him healthy or effective. However, tonight we’ll get to witness something special – a matchup between one of the most homer prone pitchers (1.90 HR/9) and a former power-hitting great. Who will win this race to the bottom? Projection systems peg Davis for around 30 percent of a home run, although they largely don’t know how to incorporate the nagging injuries which have clearly affected Khrash.

Also Consider: Mike Montgomery, Chris Owings, Pablo Reyes, DJ Stewart, Billy McKinney, Ryan McBroom, Sheldon Neuse, Jared Walsh, Rowdy Tellez, Gavin Lux, Justin Smoak

MID-TIER MUST PLAYS

Franmil Reyes –OF – Cleveland Indians (at Ross Detwiler)

Last night, the White Sox sacrificed Hector Santiago to the Indians offense, leaving him in for four innings despite allowing seven runs and three deep flies. They’re likely to do the same with Detwiler. He’s a bad lefty with a 6.98 ERA in 59.1 innings. More importantly, he’s an extremely homer prone (2.73 HR/9) ground ball pitcher. As a fly ball hitter, Reyes should feast. Multiple home runs are not out of the question. In fact, Reyes has the best chance to homer tonight.

Also Consider: Matt Chapman, Vladimir Guerrero Jr., Yasiel Puig

HIGH PRICED VALUES

Shane Bieber – SP – Cleveland Indians (at White Sox)

One of the most challenging things about the last week of the season is finding pitchers who can be reliably counted upon to toss a full outing. With the Indians just half a game back on a Wild Card slot, they have to go all out. That includes setting Bieber loose. Of course, if they build an imposing lead – as they did last night – a good Bieber outing could still end after five frames. Like any high strikeout rate pitcher, he matches up well against a volatile White Sox offense. As a team, they have one of the most extreme combinations of many strikeouts and few walks. Expect around seven innings and nine punch outs.

Also Consider: Jacob deGrom, J.D. Martinez, Anthony Rendon, Kyle Schwarber
description: Brad Johnson reviews his favorite MLB DFS bargain targets for Wednesday, September 25. (Getty Images)
